articles.headline: The Fake Americans Russia Created to Influence the Election
articles.snippet: Posing as ordinary citizens on Facebook and building “warlists” of Twitter accounts, suspected Russian agents intervened last year in the American democratic process.
articles.abstract: Posing as ordinary citizens on Facebook and building “warlists” of Twitter accounts, suspected Russian agents intervened last year in the American democratic process.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes an international offensive begins with a few shots that draw little notice. So it was last year when Melvin Redick of Harrisburg, Pa., a friendly-looking American with a backward baseball cap and a young daughter, posted on Facebook a link to a brand-new website.

articles.headline: Equifax Says Cyberattack May Have Affected 143 Million in the U.S.
articles.snippet: Criminals gained access to certain files in the company’s system from mid-May to July, according to an investigation by Equifax.
articles.abstract: Criminals gained access to certain files in the company’s system from mid-May to July, according to an investigation by Equifax.
articles.lead_paragraph: Equifax, one of the three major consumer credit reporting agencies, said on Thursday that hackers had gained access to company data that potentially compromised sensitive information for 143 million American consumers, including Social Security numbers and driver’s license numbers.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard, Tiffany Hsu, Nicole Perlroth and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: For Meningitis B Vaccines, Climbing Revenue, and Plenty of Skepticism
articles.snippet: Two drug firms have developed pricey vaccines they are advertising widely on TV, raising concerns among experts that they are stoking parents’ fears about a rare disease unnecessarily.
articles.abstract: Two drug firms have developed pricey vaccines they are advertising widely on TV, raising concerns among experts that they are stoking parents’ fears about a rare disease unnecessarily.
articles.lead_paragraph: Small college outbreaks four years ago of meningitis B — an extremely rare variation of the dangerous infection — have set off a lucrative new business: persuading parents that pricey vaccines are a loving investment for their college-bound children.

articles.headline: Caribbean Devastated as Irma Heads Toward Florida
articles.snippet: The storm turned beach paradises into half-habitable emergency zones as it headed toward Florida, where panicked residents were scrambling to find gasoline and water.
articles.abstract: The storm turned beach paradises into half-habitable emergency zones as it headed toward Florida, where panicked residents were scrambling to find gasoline and water.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — One of the most powerful Atlantic hurricanes ever recorded crescendoed over the Caribbean on Thursday, crumpling islands better known as beach paradises into half-habitable emergency zones and sideswiping Puerto Rico before churning north. It is expected to hit the Florida Keys and South Florida by Saturday night.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, Kirk Semple and Vivian Yee

articles.headline: Using Silicon Valley Tactics, LinkedIn’s Founder Is Working to Blunt Trump
articles.snippet: Reid Hoffman, who founded LinkedIn, is funding groups to create a bulwark against Mr. Trump’s agenda. Whether his start-up approach is effective is unclear.
articles.abstract: Reid Hoffman, who founded LinkedIn, is funding groups to create a bulwark against Mr. Trump’s agenda. Whether his start-up approach is effective is unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Reid Hoffman, the founder of LinkedIn and a billionaire Silicon Valley venture capitalist, has made a half-dozen or so investments in recent months with a specific aim: to counteract the influence of President Trump.

articles.headline: ‘I Smell Cash’: How the A.T.F. Spent Millions Unchecked
articles.snippet: A pair of informants got $6 million and agents spent freely. The Justice Department fought to keep records of the operation secret.
articles.abstract: A pair of informants got $6 million and agents spent freely. The Justice Department fought to keep records of the operation secret.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRISTOL, Va. — For seven years, agents at the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives followed an unwritten policy: If you needed to buy something for one of your cases, do not bother asking Washington. Talk to agents in Bristol, Va., who controlled a multimillion-dollar account unrestricted by Congress or the bureaucracy.

articles.headline: The Last Days of ISIS’ Capital: Airstrikes if You Stay, Land Mines if You Flee
articles.snippet: A Times reporter travels to Raqqa, the wounded heart of the Islamic State, and finds residents trapped by airstrikes, artillery fire and land mines.
articles.abstract: A Times reporter travels to Raqqa, the wounded heart of the Islamic State, and finds residents trapped by airstrikes, artillery fire and land mines.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAQQA, Syria — Every few minutes, a deafening boom. Then a whistle of artillery. Occasionally, the clatter of a pickup truck, piled with soldiers, advancing to the front line.
